title: Has Trump made America great again? - Quora

response.answer_text: That would have been difficult at the best of times, because the USA was never great to begin with. Let's go back to the extreme of living memory, its entry into World War II. This was delayed not only because of isolationism, but because until 1942 there were still valuable business contracts with the Germans. There was enough official sympathy for the German position that boatloads of Jewish refugees, many of them children, were turned away. During the war, USA became the first country, and the last, to use nuclear weapons against it's enemies, and has retained that option at the push of a button, in the face of 70 years of attempts to reduce the global nuclear threat by negotiation in the international community. Racism was, and still is, a core American value. Life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, not to mention the rights to free speech and to bear arms, were strictly for white people. America's privatised prisons are disproportionately stocked with black people, and they are 10 times more likely to be killed by police and security forces. That's life and liberty written off, and as for the pursuit of happiness, marijuana was criminalised for 40 years with the express intention of getting black troublemakers into custody. After World War II, returning servicemen were given financial help under the GI bill, most of which was used to purchase property. Black GIs were specifically excluded by legislation from this process, by ‘redlining’ areas of majority black occupation, so blacks could not get mortgages, or buy property, only rent from white landlords. Throughout the 50s and 60s the Southern states practised overt discrimination against black people with impunity. Racial segregation was indistinguishable from that practiced in South Africa under apartheid. The Civil Rights Movement, which brought an official end to segregation under the Kennedy administration, did very little to change attitudes, and to this day many Southerners mourn the passing of slavery and segregation with attachment to symbols of the traitorous Confederacy, and the same prejudices that characterised the slavery years. In the 1960s, the USA prosecuted pointless adventuristic wars in Southeast Asia, and war crimes against the people of Vietnam, Cambodia, and Laos, including deforestation and deagriculturalisation by the use of chemical weapons like napalm and defoliants. In the 1970s the USA propped up fascist dictatorships in South America, Israeli expansionism, and apartheid in South Africa. These continued into the 1980s with undeclared colonial wars in Central America that ruthlessly trampled on the aspirations of working people, with assassinations of the leaders and organisers, for the benefit of American business. Throughout the 90s and up to the present day, tentative steps to protect the environment, reduce pollution and greenhouse gases, were persistently nullified by administrations in the pocket of oil companies and mining interests. Many areas of the USA still do not have safe drinking water. Are we great yet? We haven't got to the Iraq and Afghan wars, which destabilized those regions for a generation, and led to the rise of the Taliban and ISIS, all the while working hand in glove with the mediaeval tyranny of the House of Saud, and making sure that any Middle East peace deal would be impossible, funnelling 2 billion dollars a year in military appropriations to Israel as if it were another state in the Union. In the early 2010s, Barack Obama pushed the rules as far as he was permitted, given the structural corruption he was working against, to make America at least hopeful of being great for the first time since the 1930s, when Roosevelt’s program of reconstruction, the New Deal, allowed some broadly socialistic principles shared by the rest of the developed world - Medicare, unemployment benefits, a minimum wage - to creep past the monopoly capitalism that both political parties have no choice but to support. So far from Making America Great Again, Trump has done his damndest to reverse the limited progress Obama achieved, stuffed the administration with sycophants and business cronies, and accelerated the downward slide into oligarchy, austerity, an infrastructural neglect that began 30 years ago under another incompetent showbiz personality, Ronald Reagan. He helped the super rich pull up the drawbridge with the benefit of generous tax cuts, and insulated them from disastrous economic consequences that ordinary Americans have to endure. Working Americans continue to get poorer in real terms than their parents and grandparents had been. Since Trump came into office, America has been abandoned by its former allies, as he embraced and kowtowed to its former enemies. In short, what very little work he has done - he plays an awful lot of golf at his own resorts on the taxpayers’ dollar - has been to guarantee that any kind of greatness was out of reach.

What could be the outcome if people fight each other in the streets based on such words? Extremely dangerous.Very unusual behavior we expect from US citizens! More than that, the horrible and terrible US news media. They impose their views on its readers/viewers! And they called it as free press and media! Highest form of journalism! Which west want to impose on rest of the world! Simply disgusting. Certainly above leftist behavior brought down America’s image across the world. Now we know US do not have a free media. They got controlled media. Media controlled from behind. Even the British BBC is imitating them or controlled by same group from behind. What a pity. The truth is there exits no free press any more. If at all such case exists, the rest of the controlled media will simply kill it. That is the saddest part for the world. The so called free world. Old America seems to be on a slow death. It is slowly being replaced with a New America, the leftist, socialist America. May be the Swedish model where people are so conditioned, that they are too willingly to loose their own freedom even. May be Trump could be the last hope for Old America. No wonder the reaction is so strong from other side. Trump in spite of all his negative points, is proving to be a strong leader who really want the well being of Americans citizens. Unlike many of the previous Presidents, Trump did honor so many of his election promises, whether you like it or agree with it or not. So far Trump proved to be very effective. Economy is flourishing. More jobs generated month after months. Trump’s N. Korea policy seems to be effective. Opposite camp is clueless how to take on him. After all they are least concerned about America, instead they want to impose a socialistic utopia in USA. As a strong leader, if Trump could mellow a bit and put some deliberate effort to unite the people, things could take a dramatic turn. However very little chance for that strategy to work in the present turbulent political scenario. After 17 months of Trump Presidency, he proves to be effective in solving problems faced by USA and its citizens. He may not be as good for other nations as one may wish. After all he is President of United States. And that is exactly what he focus too.

This is why by the way I think you will see President Trump receive twice the support from the black community and Hispanic community in 2020 than he received in 2016.Passed the First Step Act, a landmark criminal justice reform bill that undid ridiculous stuff from the past like the three strikes laws that could put people in prison for life for three minor drug incidents.Instituted Enterprise zones and Opportunity zones targeting inner cities to provide grant money and low interest loans to minorities primarily who wanted to start businesses and employ folks in these blighted citiesInstituted school choice over the objections of the democrat congress and teachers unions and targeted communities to enable lower income people to send their children to schools of their choice rather than be forced to send them to failing government schools. If we could reach out to the citizens of Pompei in their afterlife, we might find a common thread between their opinions and the citizens who have died needlessly from COVID 19 in the USA. Aside from being cremated, they spent their lives seeking to do what people typically do: to live their lives. While Vesuvius had interrupted their aspersions, so to did the Great Actions by our Commander In Chief. The end results for these individuals have become the same: cremation. It would be hard for me to say if it was more painful to die being burnt to death suddenly; or the weeks long agony for your family to endure your death. What makes today’s cremations so different and difficult to comprehend, is the fact we were warned. Pompei was not. With his “God given intellect” he had the best advisors telling him ““It would just All Go Away ~ like Magic” we can see how this has worked out, for him & the dead. And yet he still wants us to believe he is making America Great Again, for those who can survive perhaps. And for those of us who do, we can attempt to rebuild the economy and all the business which have gone, and rebuild the faith in our government after he is gone, and restructure the ways and means our society and law enforcement once worked prior to his rhetoric: ““when the looting starts, the shooting starts.” Is this the way to make America Great? It is no wonder this mindset is being protested against. We have been incised by the One Man who should have kept peace in this nation: our President. But ~ he dropped the ball, like countless others. Would we have had better chances if we had the Mighty Casey at bat? At least we would have know ahead of time, we all knew Casey Jones Struck Out. Donald couldn’t hit a home-run. He can’t even hit a line-drive. Any ball he bats turn foul, just like his ““many popular polls- great ones! So Great in fact ~ they’ll be smiling down from Heaven for what I’ve accomplished!” (In his mind, they were home-runs, but they all turned fowl.) Yes, Donald Trump has done much To this country, and For himself. He will now have something to write about in his up-and-coming book: The Apprentice Graduates, A Stay-At-Home Adventure. All this will eventually sink into even his Perfectly closed mind. What a nightmare this will be when the facades tumble down. I can feel sorry for him then, but not while he is on the horse. He will be The study of what can go wrong in a Democracy like our own, something for the textbooks on the future. In a way, he actually is the catalyst to make America Great again, indirectly tearing down the iconic hallmarks of these United States, singlehandedly toppling the Presidency like a bronze statue of General Lee. He has inadvertently changed the course of history by his ignoble actions: castigating the Senate, like Caligula; treating the people cruelly like Julius; and ignoring the fires while the city burned like Nero. Too bad Epstein was silenced, it would have been nice to have known what Jeffrey knew about Donald, all those parties and businesses dealings. They shared the same town. They shared the same tastes in women. Imagine what a conversation might have been like at one of their parties together: ““Well Don, are you enjoying my hospitality?” ““This is Great, Jeff! Only in America!” (They had it like that in Rome too, back-in-the-days of Caligula and Julius.) Absolute Power Corrupting Absolutely. Having lived the high life and all the pleasures he could consume, it is no wonder he believed he could continue this increasing power by whatever means it took, running rampant into the Oval Office, as if it were the highest position to attain, providing him bragging rights to the global elite. His Loyal advisors would restrain his actions if his wrath fell out of bounds with protocol. If he couldn’t get something done His way, he would replace the obstacle / person with someone who could. All this has played out before our eyes, our senses numbed and dumbfounded, believing our Commander In Chief would never DO That! But he did, and We The People have paid the price, some with our very lives ~ for his lies. The citizens of Pompei could not avoid their cremation, tragic as it was. The citizens of America did not deserve the avoidable tragedies which have fallen on them. Warning signs ignored, the truth obscured with arrogant lies, political power his only priority; our Leader his in a Bunker like Hitler when the Allies overtook Berlin. With Shock & Awe he had the military gas a peaceful demonstration, sending choppers low to remove the evidence from reporter’s cameras. The then he took a victory walk for his photo-op when protesters disbanded, deeming it safe to climb up from hiding 5 floors below ground. (Can’t justify the troops unless “he felt threatened”; an executive prerogative.) Will This man actually have the Secret Service around him for the rest of his life? Can’t we just give him the money and tell him to go away, hire some armed guards rather than staining the careers of more American Service Members?

Great is subjective but he has made America a whole lot better for the bottom and middle: Released two weeks ago, the Census Bureau’s report on “Income and Poverty in the United States” for 2019 clearly shows that, pre-pandemic, President Trump’s economic success blew past that of any other presidency. First, the Census Bureau reported that real median household income grew to $68,703 in 2019, an impressive 6.8% increase over 2018. It was the largest one-year increase in median income on record going back to 1967. It was also 45 percent more growth in a single year ($4,379) than Obama/Biden produced in their entire 8 years in office ($3,021). As was the case throughout Trump’s first three years, the economic benefits were widespread. While the overall growth rate was 6.8%, real median income grew by an even greater 7.9% for Black Americans, 7.1% for Hispanic Americans, and 10.6% for Asian Americans. All record highs as were the new income levels for each of these groups. In regards to Trump’s tax cuts: As for talking points about how the Trump tax cuts benefitted only the rich, well, they were false. As incomes grew in 2019, the poverty rate plummeted 1.3 percentage points to a 60 year low of 10.5%. This was the largest reduction in poverty in over 50 years. It lifted over 4.1 million people out of poverty, the largest yearly decrease since 1966. Just for comparison purposes, over the Obama/Biden era, the number of people living in poverty increased by 787,000. Minority groups again experienced the largest improvements. While the overall poverty rate declined 1.3 percentage points, Black poverty fell by 2.0 percentage points, Hispanic poverty fell by 1.8, and Asian poverty fell by 2.8. According to the White House Council of Economic Advisers (CEA) “the poverty rate fell to an all-time record low for every race and ethnic group in 2019.” Child poverty decreased to 14.4 percent, the lowest child poverty rate observed since 1973 and down from 18 percent at the end of the Obama/Biden era. So much better!

“Great again.” The question is, how will we measure “great” and “again”? What were the halcyon days of the United States and in what ways? The GDP Definition of “Great”— The White House, despite all its internal, warring factions, is defining “great” strictly in terms of economics: GDP, job numbers, and Americans’ disposable income (a questionable indicator of The American Dream). You would think that by paring down the dozens of issues that affect the U.S. and its people to these three would make it very easy to be “great.” The Historical Definition of “Again”— But maybe, not great again; even during the Reagan years, people in the bottom tiers of the U.S. socioeconomic classes were struggling, some kinds of taxes were replaced by other kinds of taxes. Unemployment tends to follow international economic swings, so the fact that things actually got worse while Reagan was president is somewhat similar to what President Obama inherited as the globe was taking an economic dive (in large part due to financial institution over-extension with debt offerings). Again? Under FDR? Truman? Nixon? Reagan? Bush #1? Bush #2? The 2017 Federal Budget Definition of “Great”— Almost every issue is now framed in terms of theories about what will make the U.S. GDP grow faster than that of other countries. The exceptions are increases in military funding, Dept. of Homeland Security funding, and a $1T investment in “infrastructure” (to be a shared expense with businesses that participate). “The Wall” is based on a different theory of economic benefits vs. the cost of construction, maintenance, and staffing. Drawing from the White House budget document, we can see the places where Americans can expect less: Major reduction in healthcare insurance availability and in healthcare services available.Reduced and eliminated financial institution regulatory oversight (reintroducing the circumstances that led to the financial institution collapse of 2007–2008)Substantial reduction in access to Medicaid, Supplemental Nutrition Assistance, temporary financial assistance (aka “welfare”), and the Children’s Health Insurance Program for families living in povertySubstantial reduction in government oversight/administration of student loansSubstantial reduction in funding for teacher training, after-school programs for children living in poverty, and programs designed to give children living in poverty and those with disabilities or other learning disadvantages a “boost” in completing their education and being prepared for post-high school education/training; move from support for public schools to greater support for private and religious K-12 schoolsReduction in support for farmers/agriculture (plus the elimination of much of the workforce that plants, tends, and picks the crops)Reduction in retirement benefits for federal employees (other than senators and House representatives)The devil is in the details. For example, a quick look at the spreadsheet in the budget document shows that the federal deficit decreases as percent of GDP for a couple years, and then it increases as percent of GDP. Another issue is whether the targets for these reductions are achievable. As an example, look at reductions in Medicaid as a way of understanding what’s behind some of these cuts. The major fraud committed with Medicaid comes from healthcare providers. (In Medicare, the major fraud is split between insurances billing for services not received by patients and healthcare providers delivering treatments that are not needed or are over-billed.) However, the “remedy” being offered in Congress and the White House is to reduce the number of people who are eligible for Medicaid. It’s not clear how remedying something other than the root cause of the problem will make things great for anyone other than those insurance companies and healthcare institutions that are unscrupulous. And then there’s this: The theories about rapid GDP growth for middle- and working-class Americans and for the working poor are based on a premise that has been proven false: When corporations make more profit, their shareholders benefit, especially if they don’t expand their workforce. By law, corporations are required to maximize shareholder returns. The stock market rise is based on the belief that corporations will continue to make record profits, not that they will expand their workforce. We’re already great! The U.S. is already great. In fact, in many ways, it’s the best it’s every been… even if you just look at GDP. Yes, the U.S. can get even better, but that’s different from claiming it’s not great now and it will be later. Unfortunately, “Make America great again!” has a sound bite advantage over “Make America even better than it’s ever been!” American nostalgia for what never was is infamously resistant to facts. U.S. Quality of Character— Since the November election the rest of the world has been judging the U.S. more harshly. They had their frustrations with G.W. Bush and Barack Obama— frustrations that pale in comparison to what they’re feeling now. They’re judging the President and the 63 million Americans who voted for him because the White House’s notions of what makes a “great” country should include a lot more than GDP. Let’s assume that a “great America” has something to do with the “quality of character” of the nation in the way that it treats its citizens, residents, and world neighbors. Quality of character includes being honest & prudentself-disciplined in behaviorrespectful of otherscollaborativewell-informedgenerous/benevolentdependablepersistent & consistentprincipled (making decisions and behaving based on fundamental ethical principles)benevolent/generous (of spirit and deed)responsible (taking responsibility for one’s words and deeds, plus looking out for all Americans, in our case)In other words, for the U.S. to be “great,” its leader(s) need to have these qualities of character. Of the eleven characteristics listed, President Trump demonstrates about one (persistent but not consistent; principled in some ways and lacking integrity in others— awarding 1/2 for each). Quality of Character and Treatment of Americans— Further marginalizing people living in poverty, including the working poor (67% of those on Medicaid), taking funds from the public schools that working-class and poor families must depend on for a quality education, and increasing the financial assets of the upper class disproportionately more than that of the middle- and working-classes are actions that are contemptuous of many, if not most, Americans. This is a consistent mentality: The wealthiest nation on Earth should do whatever it can to accelerate its economic growth, even at the expense of others. And the wealthiest individuals in the U.S. should do whatever they can to accelerate their financial growth, even at the expense of the rest of the nation. This is not a mentality we normally associate with a high quality of character. It is selfish in terms of assets and power. It applies to many in the current White House. Quality of Character and Treatment of Allies— Since the beginning of Donald Trump’s bid for the presidency, he has maligned, snubbed, and disrespected U.S. allies and their leaders while praising despots like Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong-un, and Rodrigo Duterte. His profound deficit in knowledge about world affairs is not just a deficit in being well-informed; it is actually a deliberate preference not to know the facts: He would not attend intelligence briefings after the election, deeming them a waste of his time; he says he does not like to read and prefers to base decisions on his “gut.” In a meeting with President Xi Jinping, Trump volunteered that ten minutes spent talking about North Korea introduced him to some of the complexities in dealing with Kim Jong-un and that government. (And that statement was given the same importance, by Trump, as noting that the chocolate cake they’d had was “fantastic.”) However, it is not just Donald J. Trump who is treating allies with disregard. There are others in the White House who are rabid nationalists (not just Steve Bannon, by the way). To be clear: Most members of the U.S. Congress, especially the Senate, recognize the importance of respectful and tactful international relations… especially with allies. They, too, represent the nation and, in that capacity, their quality of character should be acknowledged, at least in that regard. Can President Trump make America great again? Probably not, unless we consider only GDP and not who within the U.S. benefits from that. Surely not, if we consider the quality of character of the nation’s leadership and the nation’s domestic and foreign policies.

Here we go again. I cannot help but wonder when America stopped being great, but I do believe it began sometime around the end of 2016. It was around that time we decided that we no longer would help lead the fight against climate change. It was somewhere around that time that we decided that putting prekindergarten children in cages was a good idea. It was about that time that we decided that our historic allies were no longer worth supporting. We decided that leaders like Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong Un, President Erdogan, and the Saudi Royal family were the type of leaders we should associate with. We made the decision during this period that jailing our opposition sounded like a legitimate rally cry. The promise of the President of the United States to pay the legal fees of thugs who would attack his opposition at his rallies became the norm. To attack members of one's own party with childish nicknames and innuendoes now sounds like acceptable political strategy. I am waiting to hear the President yell “Nanna nanna boo boo" at his next debate. I have watched America's honor being questioned by the Kurds and the Ukrainians. Is this what Making America Great Again looks like? We are rapidly becoming a laughingstock among the nation's of the world. Is that the definition of Great now? We have a President who cannot speak in an orderly manner and has a vocabulary reminiscent of an elementary school student, and that is considered Great? I realize I am probably going to make some people angry, but we have to stop this insanity. Donald Trump is not characteristic of what America stands for. In fact he is the antithesis of what we have historically represented. America was Great, then we elected Donald Trump and everything just fell apart. As the famous Ricky Ricardo said, “We have some splaining to do". I know, you have to be kind of old to know about Ricky Ricardo and that quote. Look it up.

I have a great job. My 401K is doing so well that I might be able to retire YEARS earlier than expected. The economy is actually doing well for everybody not forced into unemployment by governors determining who gets to live or die. Gas prices are reasonable and I can buy toilet paper again! On a personal note, the “sky is falling” claims that those of us in the LGBTQ+ community would be marched off into gas chambers hasn’t materialized and won’t. From a climate perspective, the glaciers are still melting, and will continue to do so as long as India and China don’t have to abide by any climate accords. But we have banned plastic straws in California!!!! The world is saved!!!! We haven’t started any new wars, or invaded any countries. A cruise missile here or there, but nothing to get excited about. COVID-19 is everywhere, and every nation leader is being blamed for everything. It’s the same story in every country. Riots and (ahem) peaceful protests are breaking out in cities around the country with looting and burning down of businesses and homes. This, of course, is all Trump’s fault, just as Ferguson, Baltimore and others during the Obama-Biden administration were Obama and Biden’s fault. The police are still corrupt and shooting people of color, but they are awesome as long as they are trying to take down a president. The fact is, the typical person in America is going on with life just fine. It really doesn’t matter much who is in the White House for most of America. The Federal government is all about regulations, taxes, military, and overall economic stability. And frankly, we’re remarkably stable. Most people really couldn’t care less about all the shouting in the political landscape. It’s a very rare thing that the President does that has any direct bearing on our everyday lives. And this is the problem. As long as the people are doing well, they don’t have any compelling reason to change what seems to be working. In fact, the threat of change (we’re going to take your guns away, make you ride public transportation, raise gas taxes, etc.,) is more of a turnoff than any perceived threats to humanity Trump is said to pose. And nobody is being forced to speak Russian yet, so that narrative doesn’t seem to be flying either. Most people realize that COVID-19 is a global issue and are more angry at their mayors and governors than they are Trump. They go into the grocery store, but can’t understand why they can’t go into their church. They don’t blame Trump for that. It’s not Trump that is forcing their kids to stay home from school, it’s somebody else. Trump’s America? It’s only bleak for some. But for everybody else, it’s business as usual. As long as they don’t watch the cable new channels, which most don’t because there are dozens of scripted reality shows they’d rather watch.

Hello! I can answer that question. Trump is a magician whose only magic trick is convincing a group of backwater racists that he shares the same values as they do. Trump has mastered the art of tapping into their racist beliefs, thereby convincing them that he’s one of them, when in fact, he’s never been one of them. He grew up rich, dodged the Vietnam War and inherited the majority of his wealth. Trump’s true allegiance has always been to Trump and his willingness to maintain that allegiance is not rooted in American values. Trump will sell himself to the highest bidder no matter where they are from. The magic of Trumpism is that his followers actually believe that the huckster is a true patriot, just because he hates what they hate. So, because he’s willing to rip migrant children away from their parents at the borders or rage against black NFL protesters who want to see an end to police violence against African Americans, he’s one of them. Except when it comes to Trump’s businesses. For years, Trump—whose wife Melania is an immigrant whose parents are also permanent, legal residents and yet no one knows how this happened—has used labor outside of the United States to make his shitty wares (remember the historic television moment when David Letterman called Trump out for having his ties made in China?) So the news isn’t shocking, although it should be, that while the Trump administration and their zero-tolerance border policy left some 3,000 migrant children in custody with no idea how to reconnect them with their family, Trump’s Mar-a-Lago Club, in Palm Beach, Fla., is looking “to hire 61 foreign workers to serve as waiters and cooks during the winter social season,” the Washington Post reports. And yet, Trump’s base is not screaming about jobs being taken from Americans! There aren’t any Trump supporters talking about how this goes against the fabric of what America was built on. There have been no segments on Fox News exploring the shift in Florida economics when foreign workers take jobs from Americans. Because it’s all bullshit—all the faux outrage and drummed-up drama; all of Trump’s rants about murders and MS-13 and Mexican rapists is all bullshit and that’s the magic of Trump—his ability to say one thing while doing another and never losing his connection to the base. They don’t hold him accountable for anything. In fact, Trump has made following a Trump news cycle an Olympic event. What he says Monday holds absolutely no weight on Tuesday and no one who supports him cares. So Trump’s shitty elitist club with tons of health code violations is looking to hire 21 cooks and 40 waiters and waitresses all from overseas to work October to May and then, once their work is finished, they will be asked to return home. And no one inside the Trump administration thinks this is a bad look? Just the optics of this would be jarring for any other administration, considering how unwavering this one has been on immigration, except when it concerns the president’s family or business interests. “The postings show that—despite Trump’s insistence that immigration is holding down wages and crowding out native-born American workers—his club believes it cannot find any Americans in South Florida who are qualified to hold two very common restaurant-industry jobs,” the Washington Post reports. The Mar-a-Lago Club is not only looking to hire workers from overseas, they’re looking to pay them less than they did just a year ago. Here’s how the Washington Post breaks it down: These postings give some hints about the business Trump’s company expects at Mar-a-Lago this year—and also about what it is willing to pay workers, in a time of slowly rising wages. This year’s postings show Trump’s club wants to hire one more foreign cook than last year. But it is seeking to pay those cooks slightly less than in 2017: the posting says Mar-a-Lago’s pay for cooks starts at $13.31 per hour, down 3 cents from the year before. The posting for waiters shows Trump wants to hire five more foreigners for those jobs than in 2017. The base salary his club is offering to waiters is higher in 2018: It rose from $11.88 per hour last year to $12.68 per hour this year. The Post notes that after Trump noted that tiki-torch-wielding white supremacists in Charlottesville, Va., were “very fine people,” many longtime charity clients quit hosting events at Mar-a-Lago, which Trump has called his “Winter White House.” Now the club’s ballrooms have been rented out by “Young Republicans, the Christian Broadcasting Network and a group of superfans called ‘Trumpettes USA,’” the Post reports. I guess the one really shocking thing here is that nothing is shocking here. Trump will continue to do what he always does, which is speaking out of one side of his ass while being spanked on the other with a rolled-up Forbes magazine. And no one: not a Republican, not his followers, not the 53 percent of white woman who voted against their self-interests, can explain how any of this makes sense. So no, Trump’s not making America great again but rather the opposite… This answer is attributed to all the links applied in the text.

You know. I lived in the USA for 7 years. From 1999 to 2006. And it WAS great. From 2007 to 2016, one of my main goals was to return and live there. Because the USA was great. 2016 came and Trump got in office. And I expected as most did: “He will tone down and govern to ALL Americans, and American institutions are so strong, we will not be able to cross the line, because Americans will defend their Constitution to death”. Wheat I’ve seen happening from 2016 until today is a disgrace. I not only think America is no longer great. Trump is the symptom of a bigger problem, a problem which has been there for a long time. But the problem was contained, and Trump enabled it and set it loose, showing the world the worst of America. America was called “the leader of the free world”. In the face of this pandemic, and how Trump treated his own people and people from other countries, the are definitely not the leader anymore. They lost that position. The international community doesn’t trust America anymore. And I, myself, quit the dream of moving back to America. I quit because I don’t consider America “great” anymore. Suddenly, staying in my “shithole country” (using Trump’s definition) feels better than moving to America. But hey, that’s good news: One less immigrant “stealing American jobs”, right? Why couldn’t he “Make America Great Again”? Because America was already great before Trump. Not without its issues. But great. And it took one con-man to destroy over 200 years of building that greatness. All I can hope for the American people is, they change the Administration and work on the recovery. And it will take a lot of work and effort to rebuild from the wreck Trump is leaving. I honestly want to see America recover.

First, a disclaimer. This is MY opinion and everyone knows the saying about opinions. With that in mind, this is my answer to your question. Since Donald Trump has taken office, all we have heard is lies. We started hearing these lies during his campaign. He said he would release his tax returns and is still fighting that one in the courts. He said that he would build a wall (NOT a fence) on our southern border and have Mexico pay for it. We all knew that we would not be getting a check from the Mexican government. Many Trump supporters have said that the new USMCA trade agreement that replaced NAFTA is how we are getting paid. Most economists disagree with that perception. Now, a construction firm that has been repeatedly touted by Trump has gotten a contract to install 42 miles of border wall fencing that will cost taxpayers $30 million per mile. The budget office is investigating the bidding process on that one. Trump said his first priority would be a new healthcare reform bill to replace Obamacare. Even though the Republicans controlled both houses of Congress for the first two years Trump was in office, there was no healthcare bill. The Republicans could not come up with anything that would appeal to voters while protecting their buddies in the insurance industry. So, they abandoned work on the bill. Trump said that there would be an infrastructure repair bill that would create thousands of jobs. There has been no sign of that at all. Trump made overtures to North Korea to limit their nuclear ambitions. Just this week, foreign minister Ri Son Gwon stated, “Never again will we provide the US chief executive with another package to be used for achievements without receiving any returns,” he said. “Nothing is more hypocritical than an empty promise.” Another Trump failure on the international stage. Trump’s cancellation of our agreement with Iran has led that country to restart and accelerate their nuclear weapons program. Still yet another Trump failure on the international stage that even brought the ire of some of our main allies. Trump and the Republicans gave a permanent tax cut to the wealthy while giving a pittance with a sunset clause to the middle and lower classes. Trump’s never-ending tweets have made us a laughing stock to the entire world. His constant petty name-calling brings to mind a third-grader on the playground. No one on his staff seems to be able to control it and some even agree with it. That is a poor showing by our Executive branch in Washington. There are many more things that I could point out, but it would take too long. IMHO, Donald Trump and his ilk have put a stain on the United States that will take decades to erase. This time in our nation’s history will be looked upon by scholars as the worst time ever even exceeding the McCarthy years.

The words “Trump” and “Great” together create an oxyMoron, with a capital M.

The United States is at a crossroads. Technological change is disrupting traditional work patterns, the baby boomers have entered retirement and are intent of protecting their privileged circumstances (if they are lucky enough to have them), inequality is the highest it’s been since the gilded age. The list goes on. Negotiating these changes is never easy. Usually it takes a crisis before people put aside their personal interests and grievances and are prepared to unite to save the country by accepting the difficult choices that need to be made. Rather than do this, Donny Tantrum is riding the wave of anger and revulsion against the pace of these changes. He has a Svengali-like ability to harness these emotions and is surrounded by enablers all competing to try and catch this wave so that once Donny has left the building, they might be able to capitalize on this deep disaffection personally. Donny promised to Make America Great Again but all he’s succeeded in doing is galvanizing his supporters in the electorate so that the nation is more divided than ever, successfully doing the very opposite of Lincoln’s great ‘a house divided against itself cannot stand’ speech. Civil war is not out of the question. America’s enemies are rejoicing at this weakness and see opportunities to challenge the global order. As a result, we are living in ‘interesting times’ with a rudderless Washington cast adrift just when enlightened leadership is most needed. So, no, Trump has not ‘made America great again.’ There is no strategy, only tactics, and these had weakened American democracy and threaten the stability of the whole planet.

Trump has not made America great as simple as that. However, I also don't think he meant he has a magic wand to return America to the manufacturing era in 4 or 8 years time. His whole philosophy is Americans should stop shipping jobs overseas. Americans should think of themselves first before other nations. Don't think black/white, straight/gay, major/minor ethnic groups but think collectively as Americans. Like we used to think when challenged by external forces in the past. That is not to say these divisions do not exist but they shouldn't be magnified as the most pressing issues because at the end of the day, the difference is between the rich and the poor and if there are jobs for all, we will all get along. He has started the revolution and as many populists, he will be misunderstood, attacked and ridiculed but should the country have republican presidents for another 16/20 years, Trump would be the one laughing. I don't think he saw the opposition to be this spread across from the DNC to a press that should do reporting not give opinions to celebrities and leaders of nations. The man is fighting on all sides. He didn't need to. He was already rich and famous before he became the president. Hence, he believed in what he wanted and is ready to go down for it. He will fight till he can't. That doesn't mean he hasn't had his shortcomings and mistakes but the opponents have sought ways to blow them out of proportions. I get it that this is politics but do most gullible masses out there do? They believe with all their hearts that there exists this existential evil in the White House that is worse than Hitler. In the end, in another 15/20 years from now, historians will separate the facts from the myths about the 45th president and history will judge if it was all worth it.

Simple answer is NO. He is both a symptom of a sickness in America, which aggravates everything else that we need work on, and a direct cause of harm. But here's the real answer to your question… America has not been truly great, ever. We began through conquest of an entire continent, committing genocide. We built our early country on the backs of slaves, and continued for the entire first half of our history. Then we began our imperialistic phase, destablizing governments, and toppling them to raise up our puppets. All the while, keeping non whites and women in the position of second grade citizens, and denying them the same basic rights that white men take for granted. We place profit above all else, and by every standard measured, we rank below virtually every other industrialized nation, in terms of health outcomes, education, percentage incarcerated, crime, corruption, etc. I dont want to “Make America great again”. I dont want to return us to an even worse time. I want to make America great for the first time. I want us to take care of our sick, take care of our disabled, our elderly. I want to ensure that every young adult begins their career with the education they need to be successful, without saddling themselves with an insurmountable debt. I want everyone to have shelter, and enough food. I want to eliminate the root causes of the senseless violence and hate that permeates our culture. I want us to stop building up and increasing the size of the largest standing military in the world, and begin withdrawing from the practice of trying to the puppet masters to the world. In short, I want America to be great, not just as seen through the rose colored lenses of our own hubris, but through the eyes of the world.

I believe President Trump is on a path to define again, for a country which seems to have forgotten, the baseline characteristics of what constitutes a nation. As I read through the answers on this thread, I certainly recognize the vitriol, hatred of the president and fairly outrageous theories regarding his intent regarding the office he holds. “Make America Great Again” is a slogan any individual can dress for their own purposes, however I see in it an unusual simplicity of purpose. I believe President Trump is someone who wishes to leave a nation intact for his children’s generation, and as a father of four I would tend to agree. Nations cannot exist without defined geographic boundaries, and those boundaries must be maintained, defended and universally recognized. When they are not, for instance now with the promised incursion of thousands, nations fail by definition. These are uncomfortable truths, yet truths nonetheless. We have substantial economic capability and a government which has failed these past three generations to learn how budgets function and why balance sheets matter. My issue in this regard is not whether President Trump has the ability to correct these matters on his own, but the absolute intent of millions to disallow some of the truths he brought to the office upon his arrival. While I recognize Donald Trump’s imperfections as a person, I also recognize my own. So many who have decided President Trump is the worst American to have ever lived fail to revisit why he was elected, what this nation was attempting to accomplish at a difficult point in time. I do not wish to trade in the back and forth hatred evidenced on this thread. I find it impossible to look at fringe leadership of either party and see any possibility for finding fundamentals upon which the parties can agree. These are necessary for the nation to move forward rather than continue falling behind in any number of critical metrics. Debt, for one, will haunt us sooner than later. It is my firm belief President Trump is the best president for the nation, in his time, in my lifetime. I say that unequivocally, as I believe the statement is true and easily defensible. (For the record, I’m 47). As a very moderate conservative with strong liberal leanings, we must remember gains made for civil rights regarding all races and sexual orientation need a concrete solid nation to protect them. I do not see the left capable of producing such a nation, however I do see a president working very hard to install responsible fundamentals to a nation which is missing them entirely. No matter the political winds of today, President Trump will be viewed historically as among the most wise and necessary leaders the nation has enjoyed. We are fortunate he is here in that office at this time, however it is quite likely few of his beliefs and intentions will be heeded. This will, with certainty, be at our peril. We will fail to follow the raw facts he is laying before the country, and in retrospect he will be among the most consequential men to have held the presidential office. As a direct answer, has he made America great again? The nation is great, beyond any slogan or propaganda. And President Trump knows this. I believe, as one of his voters who is not blind to his lesser qualities, that he is laying at the nation’s feet a number of caveats our children will wish we had heeded.

Well, it depends on your point of view, as all things in politics does. If you support general deregulation (especially of the fossil fuel industry), heavy trade protectionism, tax cuts (though they mostly affected the upper echelons of tax payers), strong support for Israel, and much more aggressive immigration enforcement, then you could easily argue that the United States has become “great again” or better than it had been previously. On the other hand, if you support more business regulation, a more hospitable policy towards migrants, illegal and otherwise, as well as tax hikes for the upper echelons of our tax payers, you could argue that America has grown significantly worse than it had before. Now, if you’re talking about how his presidency has affected day to day American life, the answer is also dependent on who’s asking the question. For a large contingent of the American population, essentially nothing has changed under the Trump administration, except possibly altered tax rates. For the poorer part of America, things have gotten slightly worse. Tax cuts have had a limited impact on this income bracket, with many actually seeing higher tax rates than before. Prices of goods are rising or will rise as a result of the ongoing Trade War with China and the tensions with Iran. Drug prices are also continuing to rise and the healthcare situation of the poor is not at all in ideal shape. On the other hand, for the wealthier parts of America, life has improved to an extent. Taxes have dropped, business has been deregulated, the stock market is going great (though, it’s very debatable how much, if any, the Trump administration has contributed to the market), and Trump’s trade war has a limited affect on them. So in the end, it all ends up being based on your perspective.

That depends on who you are. The genius that came up with this slogan was smart not to define the time when America was great, or for whom it was great. Each of us has a greatest hits set of film clips in our head. While we know better, we can’t help wishing for finer simpler times, just like in the movies. By not specifying a time or an objective, this slogan leaves audiences free to make their own interpretations. They are happy to do so, and this increases their support and motivation, because they can pick and choose their own version of the American Dream. "Make America Great" would be a worthy goal for a President. But AGAIN makes all the difference. It is a divide-and-conquer word added by someone clever enough to win hearts and sink knives simultaneously. "Make America Great AGAIN" had 3 main objectives: Insult and discredit everyone currently running the country (and not just liberals)Rally those left behind by globalization (think Glory Days by Springsteen) to get angry and start dreaming again.And comfort older people and those who fear change.So now to the report card. Objective 1 gets an A (extra credit via Twitter on a daily basis).Objective 2 is a solid B (only the Trump campaign understood that this group had legitimate issues that needed to be addressed - he is being blocked (with good reason), but he is trying to do what they want ).Objective 3 is a D- (the revolving doors and the scandals do not reassure seniors or conservative thinkers)It was a brilliant slogan to win the past election, but the result is now a slightly less great nation. Maybe the new national motto should be “Divided we stand, united we fall.”

Has Trump made America great again? No, he has demolished America’s greatness. I cannot say it better than Fintan O’Toole said it in the Irish Times:. https://www.irishtimes.com/…/fintan-o-toole-donald-trump-ha… Fintan O’Toole: Donald Trump has destroyed the country he promised to make great againThe world has loved, hated and envied the US, Now, for the first time, we pity itSat, Apr 25, 2020, 06:00Fintan O'Toole Over more than two centuries, the United States has stirred a very wide range of feelings in the rest of the world: love and hatred, fear and hope, envy and contempt, awe and anger. But there is one emotion that has never been directed towards the US until now: pity. However bad things are for most other rich democracies, it is hard not to feel sorry for Americans. Most of them did not vote for Donald Trump in 2016. Yet they are locked down with a malignant narcissist who, instead of protecting his people from Covid-19, has amplified its lethality. The country Trump promised to make great again has never in its history seemed so pitiful. Will American prestige ever recover from this shameful episode? The US went into the coronavirus crisis with immense advantages: precious weeks of warning about what was coming, the world’s best concentration of medical and scientific expertise, effectively limitless financial resources, a military complex with stunning logistical capacity and most of the world’s leading technology corporations. Yet it managed to make itself the global epicenter of the pandemic. As the American writer George Packer puts it in the current edition of the Atlantic, “The United States reacted ... like Pakistan or Belarus – like a country with shoddy infrastructure and a dysfunctional government whose leaders were too corrupt or stupid to head off mass suffering.” It is one thing to be powerless in the face of a natural disaster, quite another to watch vast power being squandered in real time – willfully, malevolently, vindictively. It is one thing for governments to fail (as, in one degree or another, most governments did), quite another to watch a ruler and his supporters actively spread a deadly virus. Trump, his party and Rupert Murdoch’s Fox News became vectors of the pestilence. The grotesque spectacle of the president openly inciting people (some of them armed) to take to the streets to oppose the restrictions that save lives is the manifestation of a political death wish. What are supposed to be daily briefings on the crisis, demonstrative of national unity in the face of a shared challenge, have been used by Trump merely to sow confusion and division. They provide a recurring horror show in which all the neuroses that haunt the American subconscious dance naked on live TV. If the plague is a test, its ruling political nexus ensured that the US would fail it at a terrible cost in human lives. In the process, the idea of the US as the world’s leading nation – an idea that has shaped the past century – has all but evaporated. Other than the Trump impersonator Jair Bolsonaro in Brazil, who is now looking to the US as the exemplar of anything other than what not to do? How many people in Düsseldorf or Dublin are wishing they lived in Detroit or Dallas? It is hard to remember now but, even in 2017, when Trump took office, the conventional wisdom in the US was that the Republican Party and the broader framework of US political institutions would prevent him from doing too much damage. This was always a delusion, but the pandemic has exposed it in the most savage ways. Abject surrender What used to be called mainstream conservatism has not absorbed Trump – he has absorbed it. Almost the entire right-wing half of American politics has surrendered abjectly to him. It has sacrificed on the altar of wanton stupidity the most basic ideas of responsibility, care and even safety. Thus, even at the very end of March, 15 Republican governors had failed to order people to stay at home or to close non-essential businesses. In Alabama, for example, it was not until April 3rd that governor Kay Ivey finally issued a stay-at-home order. In Florida, the state with the highest concentration of elderly people with underlying conditions, governor Ron DeSantis, a Trump mini-me, kept the beach resorts open to students traveling from all over the US for spring break parties. Even on April 1st, when he issued restrictions, DeSantis exempted religious services and “recreational activities”. Georgia governor Brian Kemp, when he finally issued a stay-at-home order on April 1st, explained: “We didn’t know that [the virus can be spread by people without symptoms] until the last 24 hours.” This is not mere ignorance – it is deliberate and homicidal stupidity. There is, as the demonstrations this week in US cities have shown, plenty of political mileage in denying the reality of the pandemic. It is fuelled by Fox News and far-right internet sites, and it reaps for these politicians millions of dollars in donations, mostly (in an ugly irony) from older people who are most vulnerable to the coronavirus. It draws on a concoction of conspiracy theories, hatred of science, paranoia about the “deep state” and religious providentialism (God will protect the good folks) that is now very deeply infused in the mindset of the American right. Trump embodies and enacts this mindset, but he did not invent it. The US response to the coronavirus crisis has been paralysed by a contradiction that the Republicans have inserted into the heart of US democracy. On the one hand, they want to control all the levers of governmental power. On the other they have created a popular base by playing on the notion that government is innately evil and must not be trusted. The contradiction was made manifest in two of Trump’s statements on the pandemic: on the one hand that he has “total authority”, and on the other that “I don’t take responsibility at all”. Caught between authoritarian and anarchic impulses, he is incapable of coherence. Fertile ground But this is not just Donald Trump. The crisis has shown definitively that Trump’s presidency is not an aberration. It has grown on soil long prepared to receive it. The monstrous blossoming of misrule has structure and purpose and strategy behind it. There are very powerful interests who demand “freedom” in order to do as they like with the environment, society and the economy. They have infused a very large part of American culture with the belief that “freedom” is literally more important than life. My freedom to own assault weapons trumps your right not to get shot at school. Now, my freedom to go to the barber (“I Need a Haircut” read one banner this week in St Paul, Minnesota) trumps your need to avoid infection. Usually when this kind of outlandish idiocy is displaying itself, there is the comforting thought that, if things were really serious, it would all stop. People would sober up. Instead, a large part of the US has hit the bottle even harder. And the president, his party and their media allies keep supplying the drinks. There has been no moment of truth, no shock of realisation that the antics have to end. No one of any substance on the US right has stepped in to say: get a grip, people are dying here. That is the mark of how deep the trouble is for the US – it is not just that Trump has treated the crisis merely as a way to feed tribal hatreds but that this behaviour has become normalised. When the freak show is live on TV every evening, and the star is boasting about his ratings, it is not really a freak show any more. For a very large and solid bloc of Americans, it is reality. And this will get worse before it gets better. Trump has at least eight more months in power. In his inaugural address in 2017, he evoked “American carnage” and promised to make it stop. But now that the real carnage has arrived, he is revelling in it. He is in his element. As things get worse, he will pump more hatred and falsehood, more death-wish defiance of reason and decency, into the groundwater. If a new administration succeeds him in 2021, it will have to clean up the toxic dump he leaves behind. If he is re-elected, toxicity will have become the lifeblood of American politics. Either way, it will be a long time before the rest of the world can imagine America being great again.

You make the common mistake of assuming that there are quick, major changes in the country when the country changes Presidents. It doesn’t work that way. Economists don’t even agree on how long the previous President’s economic policies affect the economy. Some Obama-supporting economists were trying to claim that the economic boom and low unemployment rates that the country was experiencing just before the COVID-19 pandemic were the results of Obama policies. The biggest immediate change when a new President takes the oath of office is a change in general attitude and outlook of that President’s supporters. Actual change takes much longer, and in President Trump’s case, even longer as just about every policy he tried to implement was the subject of numerous lawsuits. Occasionally a President gets one of his major agenda items passed. We are still muddling through the clusterfuck that is Obamacare. Trump was able to get a major tax cut passed and people are still arguing about who benefits from it. This is generally a stupid argument because to benefit from a cut in Federal Income Tax, you have to actually pay the tax and the bottom half of the country doesn’t pay Federal Income Tax! The biggest changes that happen are the appointment of judges to the federal courts and the Supreme Court. These changes take time to propagate through the system. It has taken decades for activist judges to really screw up the country and it will take decades for originalist judges to unscrew things. In the meantime, President Trump can reverse Obama’s executive orders, which may improve the lives of many people. He is also working on reversing destructive federal policies and eliminating excessive federal regulations. These can also have dramatic improvements on individuals and businesses. For most people a change in President has little direct effect on their lives. It still takes Congress to pass laws and State laws are generally unaffected by who sits in the Oval Office. Up until COVID-19, I would have said that Trump’s America is about 10 to 15% greater than Obama’s America. Most of that improvement comes just from not having to listen to Obama telling us that “that is not who we are”. America’s greatness does not come from the government or its President, but from its people. As long as people have the freedoms guaranteed in our Constitution, the country will remain great. We are still the country where people use their ingenuity, their imagination and their hard work to improve their lives, often improving the lives of others along with theirs. We are still the country where any child can aspire and possibly succeed in becoming a doctor, an astronaut or even President.

It is highly unlikely based on his skills, temperament, experience, and ethical foundation. “Make America Great Again” is a campaign slogan. It is intended to elicit positive feelings from its intended audience. Each word is important. “Make” is an imperative verb. It signals immediacy of action. “America” is a proper noun. It evokes the feeling of being home and the abstract ideas of freedom, prosperity, or whatever other positive aspects the audience desires. “Great” is an indefinite comparative informal adverb. It lets the audience define what it is that is better than something else. Importantly, it is imprecise and indefinite. “Again” is an indefinite adverb. It lets the audience define a tomorrow that is compared to an undefined and imprecise past. Together the phrase elicits essentially meaningless, but warm feelings of nostalgia for an fluid past within its intended audience. Edward Bernays describes slogans such as this as engineering consent, "use of an engineering approach—that is, action based only on thorough knowledge of the situation and on the application of scientific principles and tried practices to the task of getting people to support ideas and programs." This is an example of propaganda.

Every great era of American history has its own sense of why America was great. Abraham Lincoln instilled in most Americans (at least those living in states that did not secede) that the nation’s strength and security was inextricably linked to the preservation of the Union in which every American played an important role. Teddy Roosevelt inspired everyday Americans to believe they were part of a United States that was emerging as a world leader in diplomacy, security, opportunity, trade, and innovation. His cousin, FDR, convinced Americans that collectively they could work their way out of the Great Depression and later he led America and the free world in defeating the Nazi threat. Similarly, Harry Truman established American greatness as a protector of democratic ideals and world security. Jack Kennedy set Americans on a course believing the nation could conquer any challenge, even space travel. Through his gifted rhetoric, Ronald Reagan made America feel great not only because of its military strength and diplomatic stature but because it stood as a beacon of freedom and a better life to American born and immigrants alike. Similarly, through his soaring speeches Barack Obama expanded our nation’s promise to all Americans, regardless of class, race or gender. What is the common theme? During the times described above, many Americans believed America was great and they, as Americans, were important because their president inspired those beliefs. That brings us to Donald Trump who boasts that only he can make America great. He not only boasts that he alone holds the keys to the nation’s greatness but he manages that way also. To the contrary, he pits Americans against one another dividing us by gender, race, religion, ethnicity and economic status. So, Trump will never make America great because he doesn’t inspire most Americans to believe their nation is great or that they are an important part of this nation’s greatness. Like other demagogues before him, Trump preaches that he alone can make the rest of us great. That has never worked before and it won’t work now.
